Comment: Game one of  a two game match with a friend rated around 1500 in preparation for the 2012 Chicago Open, where we both played in the U1700 section.  My friend won around 1500$...
He plays the Alekhine Defense
In this structure, black should strive for an e5 break which he preps with g7 Bg7 Nc6 etc.  White hopes to maintain his space advantage in the center and press it forward to stifle black's play.

I think O-O is more principled for black, I had sought to prove that the bishop is as useless on d7 as on c8 but this is simply untrue. My Nh4 idea should lose all advantage for white as it is a useless tempo tosser.

The fallback of black's Nb4 idea

Gaining more space on the QS.  This also kicks the knight and threatens to win material.
Gaining more space on the QS.  This also kicks the knight and threatens to win material.
Jettisoning the d pawn, Na8 looks aweful, but slowly the black knight can hope to return to the battlefield via c7.  White still holds an edge there because of time and greater harmony in his camp.

?? Reckless play hoping for complications where white will go astray.  There are two main options for white.  My opponent said in PM that he hoped for de where he plays Bb2 but I demonstrated that this is still winning for white even if white decides to give the rook for bishop as white is left with two pieces for a rook and the bishop pair in that.   I opted for Rxc5 which I thought was easier to deal with (less calculation), objectively it is worse than the other line, but not much.

Kxe7 was interesting and I couldn't see a clear way to get at the king.  I thought after missing Kxe7 that I may be worse even after the Bb5 idea, but it turns out white is still better.
